title: 113_s1598
content: The debt limit cannot be increased if a joint resolution disapproving the President's authority is enacted within 15 days of Congress receiving the certification. The joint resolution must be introduced within 3 days of receiving the certification, have no preamble, and be titled 'Joint Resolution of Disapproval.' The joint resolution must be titled 'Joint Resolution of Disapproval' and must disapprove of the President's exercise of authority to increase the debt limit within a specified timeframe. Upon receipt of a certification described in subsection (a)(1), the Speaker must notify Members to convene the House within two days. Any House committee must report a joint resolution without amendment within 5 days of introduction, or it will be discharged for further consideration. After a committee reports a joint resolution to the House or is discharged from consideration, a motion to proceed to consider the resolution must be made within six days of its introduction. The motion is not debatable and the previous question is ordered without further discussion. Reconsideration of the motion is not allowed after it has been disposed of. Upon receipt of a certification under subsection (a)(1), the Senate's majority leader can reconvene the Senate if it has adjourned for more than 2 days. The joint resolution will be considered as read, with all points of order waived. The resolution will be subject to 2 hours of debate, with no amendments or motions to reconsider the vote allowed. Upon receipt of a certification under subsection (a)(1), the Senate's majority leader can reconvene the Senate within two days. A joint resolution introduced in the Senate will be immediately placed on the calendar and subject to floor consideration within a specific timeframe. Upon receipt of a certification under subsection (a)(1), the Senate's majority leader can reconvene the Senate within two days. A joint resolution introduced in the Senate will be immediately placed on the calendar and subject to floor consideration within a specific timeframe. The date of introduction of a joint resolution is specified, with all points of order waived, and the motion to proceed is non-debatable. If agreed to, the joint resolution remains unfinished business until disposed of. The Senate's consideration of a joint resolution is limited to 10 hours, divided equally between majority and minority leaders. A motion to limit debate is allowed, but other motions like amendments or postponements are not. The vote on passage occurs immediately after consideration, with a single quorum call. The Senate's consideration of a joint resolution is limited to 10 hours, with a single quorum call at the end of the debate if requested. Appeals on procedural rulings are decided without debate. Joint resolutions of disapproval cannot be amended in either the House or the Senate. Coordination with the other House is required if a joint resolution is received before passing. The Senate's consideration of joint resolutions is limited to 10 hours, with no committee referral in the other House. If the Senate fails to act, the House's joint resolution gets expedited floor procedures. Companion measures are non-debatable in the Senate after passage. After passage of a joint resolution, the period between presentation to the President and his action on the resolution is excluded from the calendar day period for computing deadlines. Debate on a veto message in the Senate is limited to 1 hour divided between majority and minority leaders. After a joint resolution is passed, Congress has a limited time to override a presidential veto. If Congress successfully overrides the veto, the debt limit will not be raised. Rules regarding the procedure for joint resolutions are enacted by Congress as part of the rules of each House. The rules for joint resolutions allow either House to change them at any time, in line with constitutional rights. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 31 of title 31, United States Code. "Additional Presidential modification of the debt ceiling."
